title: FIX: Flush statistics before rate limiting bot

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Previously, statistics weren't flushed before applying rate limiting,
even if sleeping time was longer than statistics delay. This caused
significant delay in statistics. Now, statistics are flushed before
sleeping, if expected delay is longer than flushing delay.

Fixes #2336

title: Flush statistics before sleeping

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body: Applying rate limiting (__sleep()) on bots is done before flushing statistics. If rate limiting is high, this causes significant delay in statistic data.

title: Statistics never reset path_total value

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
IntelMQ built-in statistics feature works in the way, that after every restart of the bot, statistics are considered to be counted from 0 ([code](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/eba91a6022c6805da33fbbd9c566ebb8c6b24c73/intelmq/lib/bot.py#L126-L133)).

The statistics cache is updated in `__stats` method. Successful and failure stats are sent every time (with the respect to the delay), however the number of sent messages (lines 472-474) is updated only when a message was sent - paths are never filled with 0, the `defaultdict` is used. This means, that from the restart to the first sent message, the Redis statistic cache and IntelMQ message counter are out of sync.

Why is it important? 

I have a case with daily restarted collector that produces just a one message daily. Due to the described behavior, the cached stats are always filed with 1 - either because it wasn't updated, or because the first message was sent.

title: SQLBot throws a AttributeError on reconnect

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
This issue is only applicable for the 3.0.2 stable version, it is already fixed in develop.

The SQLBot uses the ‘engine’ variable for both the type of the sql engine (type string: sqlite/postgresql), and for the database engine object itself (type psycopg2 or sqlite3). 

In our tests this happens:
engine is set to “postgresql” (from the bot config)
_connect is called, which sets engine to psycopg2
Later the database disconnects, due to a timeout.
execute, catches the exception, which calls init.
Init tries to call lower() on engine. It expects engine to be a string, but is now the psycopg2 module.
An AttributeError is thrown, causing the message to drop (moved to the dump file). 

We have a fix in our fork https://github.com/DigitalTrustCenter/intelmq/tree/sqlbot-reconnect-issue
Since this is already fixed in develop (as SQLBot is replaced with SQLMixin), should we make a PR for the maintenance branch?

title: FIX Very slow dataplane parser due to loading the config for every event

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The Dataplane parser creates a new event for every data line. The harmonization config is not passed to this constructor.
This causes the code to load the harmonization config for every data line.

For feeds like http://dataplane.org/sshclient.txt, this will load the harmonization config almost 40,000 times. Hence it can take hours to parse all the feeds.
This fix reuses the harmonization config that is already loaded in the bot. This reduces the parse time to minutes (if not seconds).

title: FIX: CSV parser bot preserves original line ending

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
CSV parser bot recognizes the original line ending
in the input report and tries to keep it in the
output. If input has multiple different line endings,
the \r\n is used. This is what Python csv module uses
by default.

Previously, line filtering was handled in a few places,
in case of CSV data it was before creating the handler object
and required rewriting the whole CSV data, with hardcoded line
endings. For proper handling line ending, this the filtering was
moved inside the handler and now it does not depend on any line
ending.

In addition, the filtering code was extracted to remove code
duplication and the CSV dict line parser was updated to use
the original line ending.

Closes #1597

title: Multithreading causes bot to crash or not start

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
We are testing the mulithreading capabilities of IntelMQ in combination with RabbitMQ. We have found two (regression) issues that completely break mulithreaded bots:

1. The new YAML configuration format uses a global YAML object in lib/utils.py to read/write configuration. When mulithreading is enabled for a bot, each thread calls \__init__ on the bot class. Since the init function loads the configuration of the bot, this means that each thread tries to load the configuration at the same time. This causes a race condition on the YAML loader, and usually crashes the threads, and thus the bot fails to start.

2. When starting new threads for a bot, the parameter start=True is passed to the \__init__ method of the Bot class. This causes the bot at the end of the \__init__ method to call the start function, and thus start processing messages.
The problem lies in the fact that the subclasses for Bot (CollectorBot, ParserBot, ExpertBot, OutputBot) do not pass the start parameter to the (super) Bot class. This defaults the start parameter to False, hence the threads never start, and quit without doing anything.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/pipeline.py", line 267, in _receive
    retval = self.pipe.blmove(self.source_queue, self.internal_queue, 0, 'RIGHT', 'LEFT')
AttributeError: 'Redis' object has no attribute 'blmove'

Server version is 7.0.2, but the python library is 3.3.11. BLMOVE is first available in 4.0.0 (and 4.1.2 fixed a major bug https://github.com/redis/redis-py/issues/1776).

title: Shadowserver NTP Version Report parsing issue

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
It seems like last week there was a change in Shadowserver NTP Version Report's `jitter` field type. 
The clock jitter was previously represented by a float e.g. `0.976`, the change included `sys_` - becoming `sys_0.976`. The parser errors could be resolved by modifying the parser `config.py` file:
In `ntp_version` object
```python
('extra.', 'jitter', convert_float),
```
-->
```python
('extra.', 'jitter', validate_to_none),
```
But this solution could create problems down the pipeline when a type is considered. For instance if outputting to ElasticSearch and it still expects a float type instead of a string.

title: Using deprecated method of dnspython

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Indicates a good issue for first-time contributors

body:
Changelog of version 2.0.0:
> dns.resolver.resolve() has been added, allowing control of whether search lists are used. dns.resolver.query() is retained for backwards compatibility, but deprecated. The default for search list behavior can be set at in the resolver object with the use_search_by_default parameter. The default is False.

`dns.resolver.query()` is used here:

https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/651d0733f719579e96ec4b063a260023ebeadc50/intelmq/lib/harmonization.py#L705=

https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/0c6b3269ac480e47c62c9c31ff8685ba90d91f55/intelmq/bots/experts/abusix/_lib.py#L29=
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/3bbf1201ad783664985f00be4ba7a44ce5b05e8d/intelmq/bots/experts/reverse_dns/expert.py#L70=
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/0c6b3269ac480e47c62c9c31ff8685ba90d91f55/intelmq/bots/experts/cymru_whois/_lib.py#L57=

We also need backwards compatibility with dnspython < 2 (e.g. Ubuntu 20.04), so we could add a DNS-Query functon in utils with a `if version < 2 then ... else ...` switch.

title: PostgreSQL Output: Issue with Nullbytes in JSON-Data

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Nullbytes in JSON-Data (in the field `extra`) can cause troubles:
```
psycopg2.errors.UntranslatableCharacter: unsupported Unicode escape sequence
DETAIL:  \\u0000 cannot be converted to text.
CONTEXT:  JSON data, line 1: ....0\"}, \"malware\": \"Conficker\", \"payload\": {\"text\":...
PL/pgSQL function directives_from_extra(bigint,json) line 5 during statement block local variable initialization
SQL statement \"SELECT directives_from_extra(NEW.id, NEW.extra)\"
PL/pgSQL function events_insert_directives_for_row() line 3 at PERFORM"
```
A problematic extra-value can look like:
```
'{"payload": {"text": "M41\u0012)3U>\bxӾ6\u0000\u0013M6M6M4M4]4y]4ӭ4"}}'
```
Source: Microsoft CTIP

While the `json` type in postgres allows (encoded) Nullbytes in principle, some systems have a problem with that. I have not found out yet, what causes some Postgres-Systems to throw an error here, while others work.
Tested with PostgreSQL 14.4. Works fine on e.g. openSUSE Tumbleweed, but not on Ubuntu 20.04 with Postgres-APT-Repo. But the latter is a target plattform of IntelMQ, so IntelMQ should be compatible with it.

The only solution I see is to escape the Nullbytes in the SQL Output for Postgres (SQLite does not have an issue with these characters).
Working on it.

title: Fix reconnection in SQL Mixin

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Fixes #2200:
- bug: sql mixin: add missing import of `exception`
- sql mixin: properly separate parameters from internal variables
parameters show not be changed during runtime, this prevents reloading
the bot and other re-initializations (self.engine was made a class
instance)
- bug: sql mixin: reconnect on connection issues
separate the sql mixin initialization from the `__init__` to be able to
call it from inside the bot for re-connecting.
calling `self.__init__` would require at least the bot-id
calling `self._connect` would require preparing all the arguments

title: ParserBot: Fix line recovery and message dumping

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
- BUG: Fix line recovery and message dumping in ParserBot
  ParserBot.process first iterates over all message in a parsed report and
  catches the errors, saves the erroneous message and at the end dumps all
  of them in one row.
  The recover_line methods were not consistent in their use of the line
  given as parameter and the use of the _current_line class member.
  This lead to parsers always dumping the last message (_current_line
  which was active at the time of the dumping) leading to data loss for
  dumped messages for `recover_line_csv_dict` and
  `recover_line_json_stream`.
- DOC: type annotations and inline documentation
  mainly for ParserBot's recover_line methods and related
- ENH: generic csv parser: use current_line
  Use RewindableFileHandle to use the orignal current line for line recovery
- BUG: ctip parser and shadowserver parser: use current line for raw
  use the unparsed current line as string instead of the parsed line
- ENH: ctip parser: better error message for bogous reports
  reports must not be dropped silently if their format is unknown (can
  also happen because of misconfiguration)
- TST: add and update tests for correct line recovery

title: intelmqctl create log file before dropping privileges

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Preconditions:
- No log file `$logdir/intelmqctl.log` exists

`intelmqctl` is called as root instead of user intelmq, e.g. in setup scripts or by user error.
The initialization of `intelmqctl` is able to degrade its permissions to user intelmq, but first it creates the logging file:

https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/0221a2507b05dcccaea9ac239bb9e13fa48ce4bc/intelmq/bin/intelmqctl.py#L103-L121

which causes the file to have owner `root`.

Solution:
- swap the logging creation and the privilege drop

title: Add fix Blueliv collector requirements to CHANGELOG.md

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Indicates a need for improvements or additions to documentation

body:
fix #2161

# Please read the notes below and replace them with the description of you pull request

Make sure you follow the instructions in the [Developer Guide](https://intelmq.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/guide.html) - it describes how to run the test suite and which coding rules to follow.

# Commits

Please review your commits before creating a pull request. We try to keep our commit history clean.
If you had to fix something in your code and added another commit on top of your existing work, please [squash](https://blog.simontimms.com/2016/02/18/i-squash-my-pull-requests-and-you-should-too/) your commits.
This makes it a lot easier to find out why things work the way they do later on.

But please also keep in mind that one commit should only contain changes that belong together.
> The cardinal rule for creating good commits is to ensure there is only one "logical change" per commit
> - [OpenStack Wiki on GitCommitMessages](https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Structural_split_of_changes)

Thus, if your changes affect multiple files and also contains tests and documentation (which it should), it might make sense to have the tests and the documentation in a separate commit.

# Commit Messages

Please explain your changes also in the git commit message.
The commit message should contain a subject that gives an overview of the changes in the commit and is limited to 72 characters.
It should start with a capital letter and it should not end with a period.
Below the subject should be, separated by an empty line, the body of the commit message. The body should explain what the commit changes and why it changes thing the way it does.
Explain your modification and also explain why you didn't chose a different approach.
See also [How To Write a Git Commit Message](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/).

# Description

If you are following the commit message guidelines above, all the relevant information should already be part of the commit message.
If there is anything else you want to add, feel free to do this here.

title: Cymru parser_cap_program invalid hostname filtering

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Indicates that a maintainer wants help on an issue or pull request

body:
In some Team-Cymru payloads the `optional_information` entry includes `hostname: ` parameter with an IP address. This is parsed in `intelmq.bots.parsers.cymru.parser_cap_program` bot into `source.fqdn` field, which does not allow IP entries.  

There should be check to filter out IP hostnames, since we already have that data included in `source.ip` field.

The fix can be equivalent to PR #2144. Including `FQDN.is_valid` check seems overkill in this case, but I included it in the example below.

```python
elif key == 'hostname':
    # some hostnames are IP and not valid fqdn
    if not FQDN.is_valid(value) and value == ip:
        continue
    event['source.fqdn'] = value
```

title: Inefficient regular expression

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Found by CodeQL:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/6991597278b7286099212e9469f7b097af238adf/intelmq/bots/parsers/sucuri/parser.py#L25-L25

> This part of the regular expression may cause exponential backtracking on strings starting with '<!--' and containing many repetitions of '\n'. 

> Some regular expressions take a long time to match certain input strings to the point where the time it takes to match a string of length n is proportional to nk or even 2n. Such regular expressions can negatively affect performance, or even allow a malicious user to perform a Denial of Service ("DoS") attack by crafting an expensive input string for the regular expression to match.


Tracking issue for:
- [ ] https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/security/code-scanning/3

labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

The problem is, that the bot declares
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/f2b07f6fb02f091e21bde0d83009aefbf42be93b/intelmq/bots/collectors/api/collector_api.py#L40
but this attribute is part of the `Bot` class:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/f2b07f6fb02f091e21bde0d83009aefbf42be93b/intelmq/lib/bot.py#L114
and should therefore be called `_Bot__collector_empty_process` to be effective. And actually, this should just be called `_collector_empty_process`

title: Slow performance on latest release in Docker

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
I've tried to upgrade out intelmq setup to the major version 3.0.x and found that the whole processing was significantly slower. During troubleshooting I've found out that starting a bot and using the _intelmqctl_ utility takes longer than on the previous version. 


1. The throughput of bot was on average half of the previously used version. Of all the bots experts and output were the slowest compared to the previous version. Collectors and parsers were at the similar speed. 
2. Mainly the initialization takes a lot longer than before. 
3. I've tried both version 3.0.0 and the newly release 3.0.1.

title: filter expert: unable to handle empyt-string parameters not_after & not_before

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
If the `not_after` or `not_before` parameter is an empty string instead of null or non-existing, an error like this is raised:

```
filter-source-ip-exists-expert: Bot initialization failed.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/dev/intelmq/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 209, in __init__
    self.init()
  File "/dev/intelmq/intelmq/bots/experts/filter/expert.py", line 47, in init
    self.not_after = self.parse_timeattr(self.not_after)
  File "/dev/intelmq/intelmq/bots/experts/filter/expert.py", line 41, in parse_timeattr
    absolute = parser.parse(time_attr)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py", line 1368, in parse
    return DEFAULTPARSER.parse(timestr, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py", line 646, in parse
    raise ParserError("String does not contain a date: %s", timestr)
dateutil.parser._parser.ParserError: String does not contain a date: 
```

The reason is the `is not None` check, which does not cover empty strings. Empty strings are set by the manager of empty values.

title: gethostbyname expert: numeric value for parameter "gaierrors_to_ignore" crashes bot

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
If the configuration for the gethostbyname expert contains
```
    gaierrors_to_ignore: -3
```

or if you enter a (single) numeric value in the manager, which automatically saves it as integer, not as string, the bot does not start with:
```
gethostbyname-1-expert: Bot initialization failed.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/dev/intelmq/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 209, in __init__
    self.init()
  File "/dev/intelmq/intelmq/bots/experts/gethostbyname/expert.py", line 43, in init
    ignore = ignore.split(',')
AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute 'split'
```
A workaround is to encapsulate the value in quotes.

title: BUG: lib/bot: handle empty dict in destination_queues

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
the manager (or any user in the file directly) sets destination_queues
to an empty dict. the check `is not None` did not catch empty dicts,
initializing the destination pipeline even when no queues were defined.
The check is now more lax and the code handles empty dicts normally,
making them also the default value instead of None.

fixes certtools/intelmq#2034

@monoidic please check if that solves your observed error

title: Use the YAML unsafe loader instead of the safe loader

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
This lets us be backwards compatible to JSON and still dump YAML in a
readable format.

Another approach would be to first try to load JSON and only if that fails use yaml with the default loader.

title: CTIP Parser always overwrites feed.name

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The CTIP Parser always sets `feed.name` to what is found in the data:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/e098e5ef2fd25215de90138553d85f9aa4aafe5e/intelmq/bots/parsers/microsoft/parser_ctip.py#L85
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/e098e5ef2fd25215de90138553d85f9aa4aafe5e/intelmq/bots/parsers/microsoft/parser_ctip.py#L287-L288
This field should be left as is, if not explicitly required by the user, e.g. with a overwrite parameter, like it is in the Shadowserver parser.

title: SMTP output bot: add Content-Disposition MIME header

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The CSV attachments sent by the SMTP output bot are not recognized as CSV by MS Outlook.

Probably the SMTP output needs to add an additional MIME header to the attachment in the mail, so that Microsoft Outlook interprets the attachment as CSV-file.

So this:
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="somefeed.csv"
needs to be added using
https://docs.python.org/3/library/email.compat32-message.html#email.message.Message.add_header
at about this place in the IntelMQ code:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/a51276054a7c5f0744ccb90cda54a03eeed75400/intelmq/bots/outputs/smtp/output.py#L69

(assumptions only, needs to be verified)

title: CentOS 7: logging.warn deprecated? Causes test fail

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
On CentOS 7 with Python 3.6:
```
2021-07-02 15:49:04,552 - test-bot - WARNING - /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/intelmq/intelmq/bots/experts/rdap/expert.py:116: DeprecationWarning: The 'warn' method is deprecated, use 'warning' instead
```
That caused the test case to fail as this is a WARNING in the logs.

`logging.warn` is not even documented https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html

Python devs are not sure if it should stay or not: https://bugs.python.org/issue44543

title: ruamel.yaml loader and dumper: human readability / support for comments

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
277f72d019eab234501a3e91176186e673b880ba fixed the issue that comments where not preserved.
However when the runtime configuration is loaded with the default loader, as it was with the comment, and then dumped afterwards, the resulting file is formatted uglily:
```
{file-input: {bod_id: file-input, description: Reads file /assets/*.txt, group: Collectors,
name: File Input, enabled: true, module: intelmq.bots.collectors.file.collector_file,
run_mode: scheduled, parameters: {path: /assets, postfix: .txt, delete_file: false,...
```
Therefore I reverted the commit with 9a6946120c16505c1440081e850196415bb23ade, which brings back a human readable and better structured format for the `runtime.yaml`. But OTOH it breaks comments again. We need a solution to preserve both, comments and readability.

title: load_configuration does not support JSON files with tab whitespace because of ruamel loader

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
For the switch to YAML in configuration files, we switched to the ruamel.yaml loader, which supports JSON and YAML:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/cf87d90ceb928676d80974972fcb5af8dc8dc11c/intelmq/lib/utils.py#L201-L216
However, ruamel does not support JSON files with tabs as whitespace, because _YAML_ does not support tabs. As this routine is used to load various JSON files, which can be formatted howsoever the user formatted them, we need to support JSON with tabs.

As a workaround, we could catch this specific exception and fallback to the JSON loader.
Or we use a parameter to the routine like we have it for the write equivalent:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/cf87d90ceb928676d80974972fcb5af8dc8dc11c/intelmq/lib/utils.py#L222-L224

labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Indicates a good issue for first-time contributors

body:
https://intelmq.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/bots.html#filter

Currently the docs say:
> _filter_regex_ - attribute determines if the _filter_value_ shall be treated as regular expression or not.
> If this attribute is not empty, the bot uses python’s “search” function to evaluate the filter.

It is not clear from this text, that the "search" function is `re.search` and what it implies (as opposed to `re.match`) and what it means if `filter_regex` is false (exact match without regular expressions). Some examples may be useful.

And there's another FIXME in the description:

> description: filter messages (drop or pass messages) FIXME

title: Shadowserver Parser can't differentiate between "Accessible HTTP" and "Vulnerable HTTP"

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
See https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/pull/1971#issue-654792490 and https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/pull/1971#discussion_r647551806

The two feeds [Accessible HTTP Report](https://www.shadowserver.org/what-we-do/network-reporting/accessible-http-report/) and [Vulnerable HTTP Report](https://www.shadowserver.org/what-we-do/network-reporting/vulnerable-http-report/) use the same file name `scan_http`. Our feed detection is solely based on the file name and detects now `Vulnerable-HTTP`. Fortunately, the columns are identical, but this still causes a wrong feed name to be added to the data, of the file is actually from the `Accessible-HTTP` feed. Shadowserver's docs say, that the `tag` column is always `http` for the Accessible HTTP feed, so the data is still differentiable maybe?

title: Fix parsing in whitespace edge case and modify test #1862

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
# Please read the notes below and replace them with the description of you pull request

Make sure you follow the instructions in the [Developer Guide](https://intelmq.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/guide.html) - it describes how to run the test suite and which coding rules to follow.

# Commits

Please review your commits before creating a pull request. We try to keep our commit history clean.
If you had to fix something in your code and added another commit on top of your existing work, please [squash](https://blog.simontimms.com/2016/02/18/i-squash-my-pull-requests-and-you-should-too/) your commits.
This makes it a lot easier to find out why things work the way they do later on.

But please also keep in mind that one commit should only contain changes that belong together.
> The cardinal rule for creating good commits is to ensure there is only one "logical change" per commit
> - [OpenStack Wiki on GitCommitMessages](https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Structural_split_of_changes)

Thus, if your changes affect multiple files and also contains tests and documentation (which it should), it might make sense to have the tests and the documentation in a separate commit.

# Commit Messages

Please explain your changes also in the git commit message.
The commit message should contain a subject that gives an overview of the changes in the commit and is limited to 72 characters.
It should start with a capital letter and it should not end with a period.
Below the subject should be, separated by an empty line, the body of the commit message. The body should explain what the commit changes and why it changes thing the way it does.
Explain your modification and also explain why you didn't chose a different approach.
See also [How To Write a Git Commit Message](https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/).

# Description

Parsing issue with the whitespace in ': ' described in #1862

Hello,

title: ParserBot: erroneous raw line recovery in error handling

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Indicates that a maintainer wants help on an issue or pull request

body:
This logic here:

https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/7ba8b625a0189b7b2cbf86eb8d1825eeb4aac729/intelmq/lib/bot.py#L1005-L1031

does not work with all recover_line_* methods. Some methods use the parameter `line`, others use `self.current_line`. The overall logic is fine, but there is a major bug:

process collects all fails (`self.__failed` is appended with `line`) in the first loop (`for line in self.parse(report)`)
In the second loop (`for exc, line in self.__failed`), `recover_line` is called with `line`.
If `recover_line` accesses `self.current_line`, the data is wrong, as `self.current_line` is then the last line of the report, not the actual one.

Unfortunately, simply fixing some `recover_line_*` functions is not enough, the process in `self.process` needs to be thought through and eventually adapted as well.

- `self.current_line` should be deleted after the parsing end to prohibit this error in the future.
- `self.recover_line` behaviour should be harmonized, making it applicable for use in `self.parse_line` and in `self.process`
- `self.process` should be investigated

In the future we also need better tests, but that's a bigger task and I'm afraid we can't stem that on a short term. And unfortunately the issue is important, as it leads to bogus (wrong/duplicated) data in the dumps and therefore loss of data.

title: Cymru CAP Parser: Adapt to new format of 'bruteforce' category

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Previously, the bruteforce events only had the protocol in the comment, while most other categories had a (more or less) clear type-value syntax. Now, the bruteforce categories also uses the type-value syntax. That makes the parser a bit more bloated, as it needs to support both formats, the old and the new. Whereas I don't even know if this is a real switch, or just an additional format.

Interestingly the data no longer contains the application protocol (SSH in the case of the example) :/

fixes #1794

@aleksejsv

The `defaults` configuration:

  "error_dump_message": true,
  "error_log_exception": true,
  "error_log_message": true,
  "error_max_retries": 3,
  "error_procedure": "pass",

  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 606, in receive_message
    self.__current_message = libmessage.MessageFactory.unserialize(message,
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/message.py", line 72, in unserialize
    return MessageFactory.from_dict(message, harmonization=harmonization,
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/message.py", line 54, in from_dict
    return class_reference(message, auto=True, harmonization=harmonization)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/message.py", line 539, in __init__
    super().__init__(template, auto, harmonization)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/message.py", line 127, in __init__
    self.add(key, value, sanitize=True)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/message.py", line 249, in add
    raise exceptions.InvalidValue(key, old_value)
intelmq.lib.exceptions.InvalidValue: invalid value 0 (<class 'int'>) for key 'source.asn'
abusix-expert-cz: Current Message(event): None.
abusix-expert-cz: Bot will continue in 15 seconds.
abusix-expert-cz: Pipeline failed.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 269, in start
    self.process()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/intelmq/bots/experts/abusix/expert.py", line 26, in process
    event = self.receive_message()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 591, in receive_message
    message = self.__source_pipeline.receive()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/pipeline.py", line 122, in receive
    raise exceptions.PipelineError("There's already a message, first "
intelmq.lib.exceptions.PipelineError: pipeline failed - "There's already a message, first acknowledge the existing one."
abusix-expert-cz: Bot will continue in 15 seconds.
```

The bot keeps throwing these two exceptions and never stops. Expected behavior would be to follow `defaults.conf`, try it three times (even better would be to try just once for this kind of exception because the problem is obviously not going to go away) and then just dump the message and continue processing another one. However the message is never dumped (not to dump file nor the log - see the log line `Current Message(event): None.`) because it is never even loaded.

Currently the InvalidValue exceptions gets caught by a generic Exception handler:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/b7ba19ceaba219e6aa87a37784164dbdf0b3e680/intelmq/lib/bot.py#L329-L353

I believe it should be better handled in a similar fashion to DecodingError:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/b7ba19ceaba219e6aa87a37784164dbdf0b3e680/intelmq/lib/bot.py#L320-L327

title: BUG: bots/output/smtp/output.py multiple recipients

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Hi,

Either I did something wrong or mailing multiple recipients doesn't work.

I'm feeding the SMTP-Output from a sieve-expert that adds source.abuse_contact = 'mail_addr1,mail_addr2' and have configured the SMTP-output bot with "mail_to": "{ev[source.abuse_contact]}"

The code in output.py to handle this is:
```
recipients = [recipient.format(ev=event)
              for recipient
              in self.parameters.mail_to.split(',')]
```
And to my understanding this means that the split doesn't do anything since it tries to split "{ev[source.abuse_contact]}" and not 'mail_addr1,mail_addr2' 

Changing the code to
```
recipients = [recipient
              for recipient
              in self.parameters.mail_to.format(ev=event).split(',')]

```

Fixes the problem for me.

/Patrick

title: Deb packages: Failed check in postinst causes configure step to fail

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The deb packages run `intelmqctl check` in postinst:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/24f2355d0c549021a713c938d1d69a52134167c2/debian/intelmq.postinst#L16

This is fine and reports configuration errors to the administrator. However, a non-zero exit code can happen and this will cause the configure step to fail which has implications on the installation of the IntelMQ and other dependent packages. In upgrades to 2.3.0 this will cause that the Manager and API won't work.

We should therefore ignore the exit code of `intelmqctl check` in the postinst. For the `intelmqctl upgrade-config` call, it's OK to fail for non-zero exit codes, as that should not happen and would mean a bug in IntelMQ.

title: AMQP pipeline: get_queues needs to check vhost of response

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The method `Ampq._get_queues` in `intelmq.lib.pipeline` calls the RabbitMQ API endpoint `/api/queues` to get information about all currenly existing queues. The response has the queues for all vhosts the user has access to, which can be more than the vhost necessary for the brokering. Therefore, the method needs to check the response if the queue is in the relevant vhost (parameter `destination_pipeline_amqp_virtual_host`)

https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/24f2355d0c549021a713c938d1d69a52134167c2/intelmq/lib/pipeline.py#L598

The virtual host of the queue is given in the field "vhost":
```
    "vhost": "shodan"
```

So there's just a minor if statement in the set expression missing.

title: Fix/abusech parser

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
At the end of January, the **abuse.ch Feodo Tracker Botnet C2 IP Blocklist (CSV)** changed its format, breaking backward compatibility. I personally noticed only recently. Since the changes happened in 2 cycles time apart, in our case there were 2 error cases which could not be resolved by this coupled parser fix. So using the `intelmqdump` tool I reinjected the dumped messages 'per partes'. I contacted abusech, and they ensured me that the changes are final.

changes can be seen by comparing the `feodoips.txt` in this PR - changes made by abuse.ch:
- CSV header line is no longer commented
- new field added - 'c2_status'
- all fields in the CSV are now double-quoted

summarized fixes in this PR:
- fix parsing according to the current feed format
  - CSV header line parsing
  - sanitizing all fields to remove the extra double-qoutes
  - added new field `c2_status` as `status` from eCSIRT II format

- relevant changes in the abusech tests
- additionally all abusech-related discontinued feeds were removed
- minor parsing optimization - generate data lines and comments in one loop instead of 2 loops

title: Cymru whois expert bug

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
I was notified of an issue with Cymru whois expert. Here's the traceback:
```
        "traceback": [
            "Traceback (most recent call last):\n",
            "  File \".../intelmq/lib/bot.py\", line 269, in start\n    self.process()\n",
            "  File \".../intelmq/bots/experts/cymru_whois/expert.py\", line 47, in process\n    result = Cymru.query(address)\n",
            "  File \".../intelmq/bots/experts/cymru_whois/lib.py\", line 27, in query\n    for res in results:\n",
            "  File \".../intelmq/bots/experts/cymru_whois/lib.py\", line 134, in __ip_query_parse\n    if items[1]:\n",
            "IndexError: list index out of range\n"
        ]
```
While investigating it myself, I noticed that the IP addresses that run into this issue all give NXDOMAIN results when manually checked using `dig` (i.e `dig TXT  0.0.106.103.origin.asn.cymru.com` gives a status of `NOERROR` while `dig TXT 0.188.107.103.origin.asn.cymru.com` gives a status of `NXDOMAIN` and no response).
As such, I believe there's lacking error handling: `__query` seemingly just returns `[None]` in case `dns.resolver.query` fails, which then fails to be parsed by `__ip_query_parse`

title: sieve expert datetime math operations fail on second message

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The basic datetime math operations work fine on the first message, but not on the next one:

```
sieve-expert: Bot has found a problem.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 274, in start
    self.process()
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/bots/experts/sieve/expert.py", line 97, in process
    procedure = self.process_rule(rule, event)
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/bots/experts/sieve/expert.py", line 123, in process_rule
    procedure = self.process_action(action.action, event)
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/bots/experts/sieve/expert.py", line 269, in process_action
    action.value = SieveExpertBot.compute_basic_math(action, event)
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/bots/experts/sieve/expert.py", line 252, in compute_basic_math
    return (date - datetime.timedelta(minutes=parse_relative(action.value))).isoformat()
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/lib/utils.py", line 493, in parse_relative
    raise ValueError("Could not process result of regex for attribute " + repr(relative_time))
ValueError: Could not process result of regex for attribute '2021-01-11T15:25:04+00:00'
```

For debugging I printed the key/values of the `action` variable in `compute_basic_math`. In the first run it is:
```
{'key': 'time.source', 'operator': '-=', 'value': '1 hour', '_tx_position': 26, '_tx_position_end': 54, 'parent': <textx:sieve.Action instance at 0x7f315994b588>}
```
and in the second it is:
```
{'key': 'time.source', 'operator': '-=', 'value': '2021-01-11T15:25:04+00:00', '_tx_position': 26, '_tx_position_end': 54, 'parent': <textx:sieve.Action instance at 0x7f315994b588>}
```

The (probable) reason is that the new code changes the `action.value` value here: https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/pull/1696/files#diff-03fef6f11573511a58ca52162269f48eefd1504b6e139142f1c0b2a68368341fR256 and this value is then retained.

While the fix should be easy, writing a test seems not to be easy. Using multiple input messages at one is not sufficient, as the testing framework starts the bot for each message separately.

title: sieve expert: local timezone issues with relative datetime change

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Using this sieve file:
```
if :exists time.source {
        add! time.source -= '1 hour'
}
```
on a machine with non-UTC timezone (in this case +1) causes that an event with
```
"time.source": "2021-01-04T18:32:06+00:00"
```
gets translated into
```
"time.source": "2021-01-04T16:32:06+00:00"
```
Which is off by one hour.

Running the same bot with TZ=utc results in the expected time 17:32.

title: CSV Parser not treating ignored values correctly leading to exception

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
If the generic csv parser encounters a `-` as value in a column, the data is rejected by:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 978, in process
    events = list(filter(bool, value))
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/intelmq/bots/parsers/generic/parser_csv.py", line 130, in parse_line
    raise InvalidValue(key, value)
intelmq.lib.exceptions.InvalidValue: invalid value '-' (<class 'str'>) for key 'extra.cert_orgunit'
```

Example data is as simple as:
```
someheader
-
```

The reason is in these lines of code:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/4d10b2bcfd932b4ae3275e0df00f83325255e574/intelmq/bots/parsers/generic/parser_csv.py#L129-L130

If `Message.add` gets a value to be ignored (like `-`), the return value is `None`, which evaluates to False. I think changing the if-clause to `... is not False` is enough.

Please add a testcase for this.

title: CSV line recovery forces Windows line endings

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Indicates that a maintainer wants help on an issue or pull request

body:
The `recover_line_csv()` function is joining data with `\r\n`, redgardless of the source file newlines:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/a2d20df6fd4fa0386fe79e66156537336faf92b0/intelmq/lib/bot.py#L1042

This means that bot test are failing even though the parsing succeeded, because the `raw` values do not match: there is a new CR byte. As a workaround, bot tests are replacing newlines in their test files to account for that, which is not ideal solution.
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/f7a5c7adb9e6a3b8a65c6e453195fd914fe80c20/intelmq/tests/bots/parsers/generic/test_parser_csv_data_type.py#L20

title: Cymru Expert: Wrong Cache-Key Calculation

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The Cymru Expert creates a Key from an IP-Address in the following manner:
IP to Int 
Int to bin
f.e.:
8.39.215.10 => 136828682 => '0b**100000100111110101110000**1010'

When the first octet is smaller than 128 (ipv4), the resulting binary is < 32 Chars.
For the Key Calculation in the Cache you strip the IP address to 24 Chards (in ipv4), this leads to wrong information in the cache.

The upper IP leads to a key: 100110010110110101111100

When you check the same algorithm for 130.125.112.0 you will end up with the same key.
[130.125.112.0 => 2189258752 => '0b**100000100111110101110000**00000000']

This will lead to wrong information when the Cache is hit.


Suggestion:
(Line 55, intelmq/bots/experts/cymru_whois/expert.py)
            cache_key = bin(ip_integer)[2: minimum + 2]

            ip_bin = bin(ip_integer)[2:]
            if(ip_version == '4' and len(ip_bin) < 32) # check if lenght is smaller than 32, so shorten minimum
                minimum = minimum - (32 - len(ip_bin))
            cache_key = ip_bin[0:minimum]

But maybe you have a better Idea.

This will lead, that the Key is shorter than 24 Characters if the first octet of the ip is smaller than 128.

title: Abuse.ch URLhaus feed parsing error

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: documentation: feeds
labels.description: About intelmq/etc/feeds.yaml

body:
Feeds documentation suggests using generic CSV parser for this feed. However the mapping for columns brings error for lines, where there is no FQDN. Example:

```
"2020-04-03 13:11:03","http://ucto-id.cz/binr.image","offline","malware_download","ucto-id.cz","87.236.194.255","35592","CZ"
"2020-04-04 13:17:12","http://80.211.217.221/hakka/helios.x86","offline","malware_download","80.211.217.221","80.211.217.221","24806","CZ"
```

The first line is parsed fine, because the fifth column contains valid FQDN. However the second line throws InvalidValue exception, because `80.211.217.221` is obviously not valid FQDN.

Secondly, `type_translation` is ignored because the `malware_download` string is assigned to key `extra.urlhaus.threat_type`.

Also `delimeter` parameter is missing.

Fixes incoming.

```
root@#####:/tmp# pyasn_util_convert.py --single latest-bview.gz ipasn.dat
Parsing MRT/RIB archive ..  MrtTD2Record (PEER-INDEX-TABLE, collector 1347535000, 120 peers)
  MRT record 100000 @39s
  MRT record 200000 @65s
  MRT record 300000 @82s
  MRT record 400000 @97s
  MRT record 500000 @112s
  MRT record 600000 @131s
  Exception parsing prefix record 185.206.208.42/32
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/pyasn_util_convert.py", line 71, in <module>
    skip_record_on_error=args.skip_on_error)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/pyasn/mrtx.py", line 106, in parse_mrt_file
    origin = mrt.get_first_origin_as()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/pyasn/mrtx.py", line 311, in get_first_origin_as
    return path.get_origin_as()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/pyasn/mrtx.py", line 578, in get_origin_as
    assert origin  # eventually, should not be 0 (no asn 0), or None, or an empty set
AssertionError
```
- Next I tried using the pyasn==1.6.0b1 utility for downloading the data and then converting it. This worked!
```
root@#####:/tmp# pyasn_util_download.py -latestv46
Connecting to ftp://archive.routeviews.org
Finding most recent archive in /route-views4/bgpdata/2020.05/RIBS ...
Finding most recent archive in /route-views4/bgpdata/2020.04/RIBS ...
Downloading ftp://archive.routeviews.org//route-views4/bgpdata/2020.04/RIBS/rib.20200429.1600.bz2
 99%, 12189KB/s
Download complete.

root@#####:/tmp# pyasn_util_convert.py --single rib.20200429.1600.bz2 ipasn46.dat
Parsing MRT/RIB archive ..  MrtTD2Record (PEER-INDEX-TABLE, collector 2162111247, 101 peers)
  MRT record 100000 @11s
  MRT record 200000 @23s
  MRT record 300000 @37s
  MRT record 400000 @49s
  MRT record 500000 @63s
  MRT record 600000 @75s
  MRT record 700000 @87s
  MRT record 800000 @99s
  MRT record 900000 @112s
IPASN database saved (878114 IPV4 + 89765 IPV6 prefixes)
```

- The only time I successfuly managed to convert the data downloaded with IntelMQ script "update-asn-data" was when I used the repository version of pyasn (https://github.com/hadiasghari/pyasn). Also the result slightly differs from previous case.
```
root@#####:/tmp# pyasn_util_convert.py --single latest-bview.gz ipasn.dat
Parsing MRT/RIB archive ..  MrtTD2Record (PEER-INDEX-TABLE, collector 1347535000, 120 peers)
  MRT record 100000 @40s
  MRT record 200000 @72s
  MRT record 300000 @95s
  MRT record 400000 @123s
  MRT record 500000 @142s
  MRT record 600000 @162s
  MRT record 700000 @185s
  MRT record 800000 @205s
  MRT record 900000 @225s
IPASN database saved (836044 IPV4 + 90355 IPV6 prefixes)
```

- Using the pyasn==1.5.0b7 for downloading the data with pyasn_util_download.py fetches database with only IPv4 prefixes.

**Therefore I believe the conclusion is:**
* replace pyasn==1.5.0b7 for latest pyasn==1.6.0b1 in requirements.txt (it does not seem to break the asn_lookup bot)
* use pyasn_util_download.py instead of curl for downloading the data inside script update-asn-data

title: hidden bug

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Hi, I've found this hidden bug. There was no effect thanks to `harmonisation.py/import dns.resolver`, if you comment this line, the unit test fails.

See:

```python3
import dns
dns.resolver, dns.reversename, dns.exception.DNSException # AttributeError: module 'dns' has no attribute 'resolver'
```

```python3
import dns.resolver
dns.resolver, dns.reversename, dns.exception.DNSException # no problem
```

title: bots trapped in endless loop if decoding of raw message fails

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
If the message received from the pipeline is bogus and cannot be decoded by the pipeline, the bot is stuck in an endless loop and tries to process the same message over and over:
```
2020-01-24 12:07:28,164 - bot-id - ERROR - Pipeline failed.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/lib/pipeline.py", line 249, in _receive
    return utils.decode(retval)
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/lib/utils.py", line 102, in decode
    ".".format(encodings))
ValueError: Could not decode string with given encodings('utf-8',).

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 271, in start
    self.process()
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/bots/experts/sieve/expert.py", line 89, in process
    event = self.receive_message()
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 591, in receive_message
    message = self.__source_pipeline.receive()
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/lib/pipeline.py", line 124, in receive
    retval = self._receive()
  File "/.../intelmq/intelmq/lib/pipeline.py", line 251, in _receive
    raise exceptions.PipelineError(exc)
intelmq.lib.exceptions.PipelineError: pipeline failed - ValueError("Could not decode string with given encodings('utf-8',).",)
...
```

Can be simulated by inserting chars like "\xc9" into the binary string.

The Shadowserver parser recently learned to detect the feed from the file name of the report. But the feed is only detected from the first report received and fixed for all the other reports following.

`intelmqctl status` checks the PID file and then if the program running with this PID has the correct executable/python module. But we also need to check the bot-id that is running.

The test_raise_when_no_template function was bogus as it called:

self.assertRaises(RuntimeError, self.run_bot())

title: SMTP Output bot errors: login & multiple recipients

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
SMTP Output bot fails when it tries authentication:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 264, in start
    self.process()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/intelmq/bots/outputs/smtp/output.py", line 52, in process
    smtp.auth(smtp.auth_plain, user=self.username, password=self.password)
TypeError: auth() got an unexpected keyword argument 'user'
```
Parameters:
* `starttls: True`
* `ssl: False`
* `http_verify_cert: True`

https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/85d31c272a9ec4a20fd2039ca73c0fce27d31149/intelmq/bots/outputs/smtp/output.py#L53
I could bypass it by calling `smtp.login(user,pass)` instead, but I'm not sure if it's the best way.

Additionally, the bot doesn't work properly when it tries to send an email with multiple addresses.
Acording to smtplib, `mail_to` parameter of `sendmail` (which is called by `send_message`), should be a string with one address or a list, instead of a comma separated string as docs say.
It can't accept a list as a parameter because the value is later formatted.

title: Update Shadowserver parser

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
This PR is based on https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/issues/1442

I modified the bot so now it uses `extra.file_name` field that collectors add to the report. 

Main changes: 
* now only one Parser is needed instead of one parser per type of report
* report's field  `extra.file_name` MUST be present
* parameters `feedname` and `overwrite` are no longer needed
* new parameter `keep_feedname` is added to check if feedname should be overwritten
* Depending on `extra.file_name` the corresponding configuration is loaded
* Re-arrange of tests, almost all supported type of reports are tested
* I changed the values of `feed.name`, most changes are '-' for spaces 

Supported reports are in bot's README

Besides updated tests, I tested it with reports we receive and a File Collector bot.

TODOS:
* I don't have the filenames of these reports https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/issues/1442#issuecomment-529577029
* I don't have samples of `cwsandbox_url` so it is not tested.


Due to the changes I made, **it is not** back compatible with older versions of the bot.

Please have a look

title: Cymru CAP Parser can't parse optional information

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Cymru CAP Parser can't parse optional information present in the new feed $certname_$date.txt.

It raises `ValueError: Unable to parse comment 'srcport 1358 mwtype Conficker dstaddr X.X.X.X' of category 'bot'. Please report this.`

Here there are 3 sanitized lines present in the report
```
bot|BOT_IP|ASN|YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS|family: azorult;dest_addr: X.X.X.X; dest_port: 80;port: 48399;protocol: 6;|ASNNAME
bot|BOT_IP|ASN|YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS| mwtype Mirai |ASNNAME
bot|BOT_IP|ASN|YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS|srcport 24043 mwtype Conficker dstaddr X.X.X.X|ASNNAME
```
Bot's code assumes that all comments are similar to the first example, separated with ';'

These are the related lines

https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/ecf541b1d65d9f651c8ab17587c299e35629e659/intelmq/bots/parsers/cymru/parser_cap_program.py#L211

https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/ecf541b1d65d9f651c8ab17587c299e35629e659/intelmq/bots/parsers/cymru/parser_cap_program.py#L233-L240

title: MongoDB authentication: compatibility on different MongoDB and pymongo versions

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Hi,

In the new version of intelmq available in the repositories, I faced an issue regarding the bot MongoDB.
```python
        self.pymongo_3 = pymongo.version_tuple >= (3, )
        self.pymongo_35 = pymongo.version_tuple >= (3, 5)`
```
pymongo 3.5.1 is the last version supporting the old way to connect and the new.
You should change by.
```python
        self.pymongo_3 = pymongo.version_tuple >= (3, )
        self.pymongo_35 = pymongo.version_tuple > (3, 5, 1)`
```

title: ctl restart can lead to unintended stop

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
If the bot does not stop fast enough, the bot can't be started again and the operation is successful at the end, because the bot is running.

E.g.
```bash
intelmq@intelmq-prod:~$ intelmqctl restart do-portal-expert                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
Stopping bot do-portal-expert...
Bot do-portal-expert is still running.
Bot do-portal-expert is running.
```

Possibility to improve:
 1. Wait longer, possibly in a loop
 2. If stopping does not work, exit with a non-zero exit code

body:
For the bot AbusechIPParserBot, 3 feeds are handled.
'https://feodotracker.abuse.ch/downloads/ipblocklist.csv'
'https://zeustracker.abuse.ch/blocklist.php?download=ipblocklist'
'https://zeustracker.abuse.ch/blocklist.php?download=badips'

For zeustracker the header of the feed are the same.
For feodo, the header is different and you need to change this line.

fields = comments[-1].split(',')
to
fields = comments[-2].split(',')

But doing that break the other feed.
So I add a parameter call position and change the line as it:
fields = comments[-FEEDS[feed]['position']].split(',')

_Originally posted by @kalyparker in https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/issues/1415#issuecomment-501328031_

title: mismatch of our types with upstream RSIT

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
There are a couple of types which are not in RSIT. What to do with them?

 - [x] information content security > dropzone: asked on RSIT ML for input -> PR #2006 
 - [x] information content security > leak: data-leak https://github.com/enisaeu/Reference-Security-Incident-Taxonomy-Task-Force/pull/61
 - [X] intrusions > backdoor: merged into system-compromise in PR #1995
 - [x] intrusions > compromised: replace by system-compromise https://github.com/enisaeu/Reference-Security-Incident-Taxonomy-Task-Force/pull/59 -> PR #1993
 - [x] intrusions > defacement: replace by unauthorised-information-modification and a specific identifier https://github.com/enisaeu/Reference-Security-Incident-Taxonomy-Task-Force/pull/73 -> PR #1994
 - [x] intrusions > unauthorized-command not accepted upstream: https://github.com/enisaeu/Reference-Security-Incident-Taxonomy-Task-Force/pull/49 replacement system-compromise: https://github.com/enisaeu/Reference-Security-Incident-Taxonomy-Task-Force/pull/59  -> PR #1993
 - [x] intrusions > unauthorized-login not accepted upstream: https://github.com/enisaeu/Reference-Security-Incident-Taxonomy-Task-Force/pull/49 replacement system-compromise: https://github.com/enisaeu/Reference-Security-Incident-Taxonomy-Task-Force/pull/59  -> PR #1993
 - [x] malicious code > dga domain: ~https://github.com/enisaeu/Reference-Security-Incident-Taxonomy-Task-Force/pull/32~ Rejected by RSIT, see #1613; replace by other > dga-domain -> PR #1992
 - [x] malicious code > malware: replace by infected-system or malware-distribution, PR #1917 
 - [x] malicious code > ransomware: replace by infected-system
 - [x] other > proxy: Other can deviate from RSIT
 - [x] other > tor: Other can deviate from RSIT
 - [x] other > unknown: different name https://github.com/enisaeu/Reference-Security-Incident-Taxonomy-Task-Force/pull/46
 - [x] vulnerable > vulnerable client: vulnerable-system
 - [x] vulnerable > vulnerable service: vulnerable-system
 - [x] `information content security` -> `information-content-security` (taxonomy expert)

title: TCP output should be usable with non-intelmq TCP collectors (e.g. filebeat)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
[Commit](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/commit/0a38acf096b4934048432360fdfaf041f9fd1eb6) `0a38acf096b4934048432360fdfaf041f9fd1eb6` broke the TCP output bot behavior for certain use-cases.

Until that commit it was possible to construct a pipeline extending beyond *IntelMQ*, that would process the data using a `filebeat` -> `logstash` -> `elasticsearch` pipeline. This is no longer possible, as the aforementioned commit broke communication between the TCP output bot and the filebeat element (specifically by waiting for the `"Ok"` message using `recv`, which does not appear to be sent by `filebeat`).

More information about the issue along with a specific filebeat configuration to replicate this issue was discussed [here](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/commit/0a38acf096b4934048432360fdfaf041f9fd1eb6#r32477400).

title: Update taxonomies to current RSIT and vice-versa

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
There are currently multiple mismatches as noted in #1350 

Our taxonomies are using a space character while the enisa version uses dashes. E.g. `malicious code` (intelmq) vs `malicious-code` (enisa). A summary of our differences:

From the taxonomy expert bot code, in intelmq but in not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "dropzone": "information content security",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "leak": "information content security",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "backdoor": "intrusions",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "compromised": "intrusions",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy,
 - [ ] "defacement": "intrusions",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "unauthorized-command": "intrusions",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "unauthorized-login": "intrusions",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [x] "botnet drone": "malicious code",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy, deprecated -> infected system
 - [ ] "dga domain": "malicious code",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "malware": "malicious code",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "ransomware": "malicious code",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "other": "other",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "proxy": "other",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "tor": "other",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "unknown": "other",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "vulnerable client": "vulnerable",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy
 - [ ] "vulnerable service": "vulnerable",  # not in ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy

Differently named types:
 - [x] "ids alert": "intrusion attempts",  # ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy: 'ids-alert'
 - [x] "c&c": "malicious code",  # ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy: 'c2server'
 - [x] "infected system": "malicious code",  # ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy: 'infected-system'
 - [x] "malware configuration": "malicious code",  # ENISA eCSIRT-II taxonomy: 'malware-configuration'

From an intelmq perspective we always need to care about backwards compatibility.

cc @aaronkaplan @th-certbund 

https://github.com/enisaeu/Reference-Security-Incident-Taxonomy-Task-Force

title: changes in redis-py 3

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
>  * Only bytes, strings and numbers (ints, longs and floats) are acceptable
>    for keys and values. Previously redis-py attempted to cast other types
>    to str() and store the result. This caused must confusion and frustration
>    when passing boolean values (cast to 'True' and 'False') or None values
>    (cast to 'None'). It is now the user's responsibility to cast all
>    key names and values to bytes, strings or numbers before passing the
>    value to redis-py.

-> #1354 

>  * The StrictRedis class has been renamed to Redis. StrictRedis will
>    continue to exist as an alias of Redis for the forseeable future.
>  * The legacy Redis client class has been removed. It caused much confusion
>    to users.

The redis output uses StrictRedis.

The wait expert, test, cache, pipeline use Redis. I do not see errors in the tests for them.

title: Assigning a dictionary to the "extra" field does not handle missing keys or empty values correctly

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
IntelMQ 1.1 changed how the `"extra"` field works but tries to provide a
backwards compatible interface. In particular, it's still possible to
assign a new dictionary to `"extra"` with add method with
`overwrite=True`. There are at least two cases that are not handled
correctly when doing this:

 * Keys not present in the new dictionary that were present before are
   not removed
   
 * Keys with empty values, e.g. empty dictionaries, are ignored and
   therefore are not changed.


Example session:

```python console
>>> import intelmq.lib.message
>>> m = intelmq.lib.message.Event()
>>> m["extra"] = {"a": {"x": 1}, "b": "foo"}
>>> m["extra"]
'{"b": "foo", "a": {"x": 1}}'
```

so far, so good.

```python console
>>> m.add("extra", {"a": {}}, overwrite=True)
True
>>> m["extra"]
'{"b": "foo", "a": {"x": 1}}'
```

I would have expected this to return `{"a": {}}`

title: Stopping bots with error procedure pass and pipeline errors

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Reported via intelmq-users

https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/1.1.0/intelmq/lib/bot.py#L258
```python
                        # error_procedure: pass and pipeline problem
                        else:
                            self.stop()
```

Should be revisited.

quoting myself: https://lists.cert.at/pipermail/intelmq-users/2018-October/000074.html
> If the error_procedure
is pass and there are pipeline problems, the bot stops (in bot.py search
for "error_procedure: pass and pipeline problem"). AFAIR the reasoning
for this was/is that if the bot would not stop, the pipeline would be
kind of DOS'ed. But as problems with memory and snapshots in redis are
handled better now, that could be relaxed.

title: CleanMX source time parsing issue

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
We hit some problems reading IntelMQ CleanMX records using Logstash. The issue appears to be a missing `time.source` field in the IntelMQ records, so the processing failed.  Sample event from CleanMX feed:

``` <line>1</line>
    <id>...</id>
    <first>1537934441</first>
    <last>0</last>
    <md5>...</md5>
    <virustotal></virustotal>
    <vt_score></vt_score>
    <vt_info><![CDATA[]]></vt_info>
    <scanner>...</scanner>
    <virusname><![CDATA[clean+site]]></virusname>
    <url><![CDATA[http://.../]]></url>
    <recent>up</recent>
    <response>alive</response>
    <ip>1.1.1.1</ip>
    <as>AS1</as>
    <review>2.2.2.2</review>
    <domain>...</domain>
    <country>..</country>
    <source>.....</source>
    <email>abuse@example.com</email>
    <inetnum>...</inetnum>
    <netname>...</netname>
    <descr>...</descr>
    <ns1>...</ns1>
    <ns2>...</ns2>
    <ns3></ns3>
    <ns4></ns4>
    <ns5></ns5>
```

Output after IntelMQ processing:

```
{"feed.name": "CleanMX", "source.geolocation.city": "...", "source.asn": ..., "feed.accuracy": 100.0, "extra": {"id": "...", "inetnum": "...", "response": "alive", "source": "...", "review": "...", "scanner": "...", "ns1": "...", "ns2": "...", "descr": "...", "netname": "..."}, "status": "online", "feed.provider": "CleanMX", "source.domain_suffix": "...", "malware.hash.md5": "...", "source.geolocation.longitude": ..., "source.geolocation.cc": "..", "classification.type": "malware", "malware.name": "clean+site", "classification.taxonomy": "malicious code", "source.abuse_contact": "...", "time.observation": "2018-09-26T04:15:31+00:00", "source.url": "...", "source.geolocation.latitude": ..., "source.ip": "...", "source.fqdn": "...", "feed.url": "https://support.clean-mx.com/clean-mx/xmlviruses?response=alive&format=xml&country=.."}
```

With no `time.source` as you can see.

https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/develop/intelmq/bots/parsers/cleanmx/parser.py#L36:

```
VIRUS = OrderedDict([
    ("line", "__IGNORE__"),
    ("id", "extra"),
    ("sub", "extra"),
    ("first", "__IGNORE__"),
("firsttime", "time.source"),
...
```

Since the firsttime field is missing, that would make sense no time.source is recorded.

The code fix seems relatively easy, but I'm wondering if someone experienced with the CleanMX feed knows if this is a recent change to the feed format we need to account for in some other way.

title: bot debugger requires configured source pipeline

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Image a bot which has no configured source pipeline and we use `intelmqctl run bot-id process` to run it for testing purposes:
```
$ intelmqctl run abuse-contacts-sieve-expert process -d -m '{"source.ip": "194.33.108.254", "source.abuse_contact": "abuse@kapper.net", "source.asn": 8972}' -s
intelmqctl: Starting abuse-contacts-sieve-expert...
abuse-contacts-sieve-expert: SieveExpertBot initialized with id abuse-contacts-sieve-expert and intelmq 1.1.0.rc2 and python 3.4.2 (default, Oct  8 2014, 10:45:20) as process 12951.
abuse-contacts-sieve-expert: Bot is starting.
abuse-contacts-sieve-expert: Pipeline ready.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/intelmqctl", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('intelmq==1.1.0.rc1', 'console_scripts', 'intelmqctl')()
  File "/home/aaron/intelmq/intelmq/bin/intelmqctl.py", line 1211, in main
    return x.run()
  File "/home/aaron/intelmq/intelmq/bin/intelmqctl.py", line 636, in run
    retval, results = args.func(**args_dict)
  File "/home/aaron/intelmq/intelmq/bin/intelmqctl.py", line 643, in bot_run
    return self.bot_process_manager.bot_run(**kwargs), None
  File "/home/aaron/intelmq/intelmq/bin/intelmqctl.py", line 158, in bot_run
    loglevel=loglevel)
  File "/home/aaron/intelmq/intelmq/lib/bot_debugger.py", line 59, in __init__
    self._process(dryrun, msg, show)
  File "/home/aaron/intelmq/intelmq/lib/bot_debugger.py", line 122, in _process
    self.instance._Bot__source_pipeline.receive = lambda: msg
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'receive'
```

`self.instance._Bot__source_pipeline` is None because the pipeline is unconfigured.

We do not need a configured source pipeline to run this. We could mimick it if unconfigured. Or just do proper error handling and require it.

Not a release blocker.

title: event.get("extra") returns None even if event["extra"] would return a dictionary

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body: In IntelMQ 1.1 the way the `extra` field is handled has changed, but for backwards compatibility it's still possible to access it with just the key `"extra"` (#1046). This works fine with the `__getitem__` and `__contains__` methods but does not work with the `get` method. If there are any values in the `extra` field so that  event["extra"] would return a dictionary, `event.get("extra")` will still return `None`.

title: Return value of restart command

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Both start and stop command returned tuple (exit-status, string). Restart command returned ((exit-status-of-stop, string-of-stop), (exit-status-of-start, string-of-start)). Since exit-status was a tuple instead of a number, in the terminal error pipe received that tuple. Since intelmq-manager read only output-pipe, it wasn't aware of this incorrect behaviour. With my another pull request, intelmq-manager now handles error-pipe too, so that restart command stopped working.

Old wrong behaviour:

```bash
www-data@jezevec:~$ PATH=~/.local/bin intelmqctl restart abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser
intelmqctl: abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser was NOT RUNNING.
intelmqctl: Starting abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser...
intelmqctl: abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser is running.
(0, 'stopped')
www-data@jezevec:~$ PATH=~/.local/bin intelmqctl --type json restart abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser
[0, "running"]
(0, 'stopped')
```

New correct behaviour:

```bash
www-data@jezevec:~$ PATH=~/.local/bin intelmqctl restart abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser
intelmqctl: Stopping abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser...
intelmqctl: abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser is stopped.
intelmqctl: Starting abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser...
intelmqctl: abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser is running.
www-data@jezevec:~$ PATH=~/.local/bin intelmqctl --type json restart abuse-ch-feodo-tracker-domains-parser
["stopped", "running"]
```

Note that the return value reflects both operations, `bot_start` and `bot_stop` as seems intended by previous programmer.

title: CleanMX Parser bot (XML format)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Current CleanMX Parser is not dealing with bad data from the CleanMX feed on CSV format. Since there is a XML format available with the same data, I suggest to use it instead of csv format. During the development of this parser I found out that http collector bot sometimes hangs on this [line](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/develop/intelmq/bots/collectors/http/collector_http.py#L66) because `.text` tries to discover the best encoding (when is not provided) and in case the report is big (like CleanMX reports) the bot stops on that line and never come back.

from http://docs.python-requests.org/en/master/api/#encodings

> _If Response.encoding is None, encoding will be guessed using chardet._
>
> _The encoding of the response content is determined based solely on HTTP headers, following RFC 2616 to the letter. If you can take advantage of non-HTTP knowledge to make a better guess at the encoding, you should set r.encoding appropriately before accessing this property._

title: performance degradation for extra fields

body:
I have noticed severe performance degradation in bots caused by commit 50eb548f57444e87063b456903b38eb9bbb23ed8 to file `intelmq/lib/message.py`

Here are two runs with commit 50eb548f57444e87063b456903b38eb9bbb23ed8 and prior commit 6ccaf3b82b051749164b0884607b5c161b142056

Logging is set as follows

    "log_processed_messages_count": 10000,
    "log_processed_messages_seconds": 300,
```

First run is with commit 6ccaf3b82b051749164b0884607b5c161b142056 and the bot is run for _**5 minutes**_

The bot processed approx _**1,20,000**_ messages in _**5 minutes**_.

title: Rules for harmonization keys not enforced and not sufficient

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The current [data harmonization docs say](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/9fb52b38d6b56a099c1b6de0a0b4d663d386a243/docs/Data-Harmonization.md#rules-for-keys) that any key must match the regular expression `[a-z_.]`. Actually this is not enough, as `extra.` shouldn't be allowed just as `extra..foo`.

Currently both keys are allowed too, as it only checks if they exists in the harmonization configuration and, if the type is a JSONDict anything behind the dot is not checked.

title: Catch warnings from warnings module

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Warnings issues with `warnings.warn` are not logged by our logger. The logging module provides an interface to catch them and log them as normal warnings.

`warnings.warn` is used in modules without access to the logger.

title: ctl does not check if a running process is really the bot

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
when intelmqctl checks if a bot is running it looks up the pid and then looks if a processes with this pid is running. ctl does not check if the process is really the bot but something else.

To reproduce create a pid file of any configured bot and write some PID of another running process into it. intelmqctl will say the bot runs and can't kill it because of missing permissions. The latter is correct, the former not.

The solution would be to remove the pid if the running process executable does not match the expected executable.

title: pymongo 3.0 deprecates used insert method

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Excerpt from [changelog](https://github.com/mongodb/mongo-python-driver/blob/0b0f045d56176807edea9e547ab6a1288740a5d8/doc/changelog.rst#classpymongocollectioncollection-changes) of pymongo version 3.0:

> The following methods are deprecated:
    ...
    :meth:`~pymongo.collection.Collection.insert`

We are using exactly this method to insert data into mongodb databases. `insert_one` should be used now (introduced in version 3.0). There is no date/version given for the method removal, however we should be prepared and be future-compatible before things break somewhere.

FYI @vince-nayal and @CNCS-PT (authors of the bot)

title: pymongo >= 3.5: authentication changes

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Excerpt from [changelog](https://github.com/mongodb/mongo-python-driver/blob/0b0f045d56176807edea9e547ab6a1288740a5d8/doc/changelog.rst#changes-in-version-35) of newly released pymongo version 3.5:

> - Username and password can be passed to
>   :class:`~pymongo.mongo_client.MongoClient` as keyword arguments. Before, the
>   only way to pass them was in the URI. 

And: 

> Deprecated :meth:`~pymongo.database.Database.authenticate`. Authenticating multiple users conflicts with support for logical sessions in MongoDB 3.6. To authenticate as multiple users, create multiple instances of :class:`~pymongo.mongo_client.MongoClient`.

We are currently using this method for authentication. I suggest to use the new authentication for newer versions of pymongo and use the newer for anything >= 3.5. with pymongo 3.6 this needs to be done, otherwise the bot will be broken.

FYI @vince-nayal and @CNCS-PT (authors of the bot)
