title: VXVault Parser Error

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The VXVault Parser was giving me the following error:

```
2017-07-05 15:01:17,325 - vxvault-parser - ERROR - Failed to parse line.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 643, in process
    events = list(filter(bool, self.parse_line(line, report)))
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/intelmq/bots/parsers/vxvault/parser.py", line 39, in parse_line
    event.add("time.source", self.tempdata[1])
  File "/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/intelmq/lib/message.py", line 205, in add
    raise exceptions.InvalidValue(key, old_value)
intelmq.lib.exceptions.InvalidValue: invalid value 'VX Vault last 100 Links' (<class 'str'>) for key 'time.source'
```
I downloaded the report from [http://vxvault.net/URL_List.php](url) using `wget` and when I opened it, I saw that it has an extra line:

```
<pre>
VX Vault last 100 Links
Wed, 05 Jul 2017 14:12:27 +0000

http://stomkgmu.ru/wstat/svchost.exe
http://dtechgroup.com/r6.php?cmd=e
http://fortuma.co/scu.exe
http://lucabartoleschi.it/r6.php?cmd=e
http://exploitoru.us/anyi.jpg
...
```

So the code of the script for the VXVault parser must be updated, lines 12 and 13:

```
self.tempdata = report_split[:2]
for line in report_split[3:]:
```
should be changed to:
```
 self.tempdata = report_split[:3]
for line in report_split[4:]:
```
and also the line 39:
`
event.add("time.source", self.tempdata[1])`

should be changed to:

`event.add("time.source", self.tempdata[2])`

title: ASNs < 0  and > 4294967295 should be rejected

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Because they are invalid by definition

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet)
> The first and last ASNs of the original 16-bit integers, namely 0 and 65,535, and the last ASN of the 32-bit numbers, namely 4,294,967,295 are reserved and should not be used by operators.

The reserved ones (by RFC 6996) can be removed with the rfc1918 expert, but they are valid.

title: Looping on mailbox URL messages with no content

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
IntelMQ newbie here: wanted to get feedback on the right way to do this rather than submit a pull request just yet.

I had an issue with an email report containing a URL, where the URL content is 0 bytes. This caused lib/message.py:212 to raise InvalidValue, and the bot exits and restarts. 

```
2017-05-30 23:00:01,926 - shadowserver-url-collector - ERROR - Bot has found a problem.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/intelmq/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/intelmq-1.0.0.dev7-py3.5.egg/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 150, in start
    self.process()
  File "/opt/intelmq/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/intelmq-1.0.0.dev7-py3.5.egg/intelmq/bots/collectors/mail/collector_mail_url.py", line 87, in process
    self.chunk_replicate_header):
  File "/opt/intelmq/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/intelmq-1.0.0.dev7-py3.5.egg/intelmq/lib/splitreports.py", line 152, in generate_reports
    report.add("raw", infile.read(), force=True)
  File "/opt/intelmq/venv/lib/python3.5/site-packages/intelmq-1.0.0.dev7-py3.5.egg/intelmq/lib/message.py", line 212, in add
    raise exceptions.InvalidValue(key, value, reason=valid_value[1])
intelmq.lib.exceptions.InvalidValue: invalid value '' (<class 'str'>) for key 'raw' is_valid returned False.
```

Since the problem report didn't get marked as read before the bot restart, the collector_mail_url.py bot would get permanently stuck in the mailbox trying and failing to process that one report.

A quick fix was modifying this code in collector_mail_url.py:

```
                        self.logger.info("Report downloaded.")

                        if len(resp.content) > 0:
                            template = self.new_report()

                            for report in generate_reports(template, io.BytesIO(resp.content),
                                                           self.chunk_size,
                                                           self.chunk_replicate_header):
                                self.send_message(report)
                        else:
                            self.logger.error("Report for {} was empty".format(url))

                        # Only mark read if message relevant to this instance,
                        # so other instances watching this mailbox will still
                        # check it.
                        mailbox.mark_seen(uid)
```

I'd imagine there would be more situations where we have a permanent failure in a report URL, but we never mark the problem mail as read. Perhaps we need to specify other conditions between temporary failures and a permanent inability to process a report - I'm wondering if this is the right place to do it.

title: Bots Started by IntelMQ Manager Won't Stop

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
I managed to install IntelMQ in a CentOS 7. And I used the following commands:
```
yum install epel-release
yum install python34 python34-devel
yum install git gcc gcc-c++
yum install redis
curl "https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py" -o "/tmp/get-pip.py"
python3.4 /tmp/get-pip.py
systemctl enable redis
systemctl start redis
pip3 install typing

git clone https://github.com/certtools/intelmq.git /tmp/intelmq
cd /tmp/intelmq
sudo -s

pip3 install -r REQUIREMENTS
pip3 install .

useradd -d /opt/intelmq -U -s /bin/bash intelmq
chmod -R 0770 /opt/intelmq
chown -R intelmq.intelmq /opt/intelmq
cd /opt/intelmq/etc
cp -a examples/* .
```
Then I had to copy the files `.bashrc` and ` .bash_profile` from the directory `/root` to the directory `/opt/intelmq/` because everytime I tried to change to the intelmq user, instead of appearing `[intelmq@localhost]$` it would appear `bash-4.2$`.

After this I installed IntelMQ Manager with the following commands:
```
yum install git httpd php
systemctl enable httpd
systemctl start httpd

git clone https://github.com/certtools/intelmq-manager.git /tmp/intelmq-manager
cp -R /tmp/intelmq-manager/intelmq-manager/* /var/www/
chown -R apache.apache /var/www/html/
```
```
sed -i 's|Defaults    requiretty|Defaults    !requiretty|g' /etc/sudoers

usermod -a -G intelmq apache
```

I added this line to the visudo file:
`apache ALL=(intelmq) NOPASSWD: /usr/bin/intelmqctl`

```
sed -i 's|#!/usr/bin/env python|#!/usr/bin/env python3.4|g' /usr/bin/intelmqctl
sed -i 's|SELINUX=enforcing|SELINUX=disabled|g' /etc/selinux/config

firewall-cmd --add-service http
firewall-cmd --add-service http --permanent

reboot
```

And the problem is: if I start/stop the bots using` intelmqctl ` it works perfectly, but if I start the bots using IntelMQ Manager they will start normally, but if I try to stop them it won't do anything. I also tried to stop them with `intelmqctl` after they were started by IntelMQ Manager and this is what happens:

```
[intelmq@localhost intelmq]$ intelmqctl stop ip-fileinput-collector
intelmqctl: Stopping ip-fileinput-collector...
intelmqctl: ip-fileinput-collector is still running.
```
And if I go to the `intelmqctl `log file it shows this:
```
2017-05-26 11:49:10,969 - intelmqctl - INFO - Stopping ip-fileinput-collector...
2017-05-26 11:49:11,472 - intelmqctl - ERROR - ip-fileinput-collector is still running.

Do you know what may be causing this? Have I failed something during the installation?

title: Binary data handling and especially NUL bytes

```python

  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/csv.py", line 110, in __next__
    row = next(self.reader)
_csv.Error: line contains NULL byte
```
Further lines can't be parsed.

We ask upstream Shadowserver for a solution and an intermediate solution would be the removal of all NULL bytes before parsing.

title: Generic Mail URL Fetcher hangs forever on Downloading report

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
On our customers production system it was discovered today, that some of the collector_mail_url bots were hanging (four out of 19).  The symptoms were Identical in all cases:

* The last log message was:
  ```INFO - Downloading report from https://example.com/valid/download/url```
* intelmqctl status showed the bot as "is running"
* stracing the hanging bots process showed an read in progress:  ```read(7,```
* `ss -tpn` showed an hanging connection:
   ```CLOSE-WAIT 97     0             10.0.0.1:60822        10.0.0.2:993    users:(("python3",5627,5))```
  but as you can see this is IMAP, not the download, I suspect the imap part of the bot was waiting for the dl to finish.

Maybe the bots should get a hard timeout for all network operations, so that if something gets stuck they get restarted (some kind of watchdog).?

title: Generic CSV-Parser broken when reading column-definition from a string value

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Currently the generic CSV Parser does only parse one line correctly, when the columns are a configured as a string (this especially happens when you are using the manager for example).

Currently the first line (not header) is read and resolved according to the column definition. All following lines are not resolved and added as raw.

If the following patch is applied all lines will be read and resolved again:

```
diff --git a/intelmq/bots/parsers/generic/parser_csv.py b/intelmq/bots/parsers/generic/parser_csv.py
index 29ee44a..ae4e78d 100644
--- a/intelmq/bots/parsers/generic/parser_csv.py
+++ b/intelmq/bots/parsers/generic/parser_csv.py
@@ -30,7 +30,7 @@ def parse(self, report):
         self.columns = self.parameters.columns
         # convert columns to an array
         if type(self.parameters.columns) is str:
-            self.columns = map(str.strip, self.columns.split(","))
+            self.columns = self.columns.split(",")
 
         if hasattr(self.parameters, 'type_translation'):
             self.type_translation = json.loads(self.parameters.type_translation)
```


I have no Idea where the `map` statement originated from. My original code-fragment did not contain it.

title: Discrepancy between project description and realtiy

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Indicates a need for improvements or additions to documentation

body:
>  IntelMQ is a solution to process data feeds, pastebins, tweets through a message queue.

And then in the readme:

> IntelMQ is a solution for CERTs for collecting and processing security feeds, pastebins, tweets and log files using a message queuing protocol. It's a community driven initiative called IHAP (Incident Handling Automation Project) which was conceptually designed by European CERTs during several InfoSec events. Its main goal is to give to incident responders an easy way to collect & process threat intelligence thus improving the incident handling processes of CERTs.

We neither support pastebin, not tweets or log files. But we could.

Assigning this to @aaronkaplan as he knows the goals of this project best.

title: intelmqdump no longer working

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The commit af1bd9645408cad99e2b7325a406d541e3796384 broke intelmqdump, specifically the following section in intelmqdump.py:

```
if answer not in available_opts:
     print('Action not allowed.')
     continue
```

The problem is that `available_opts` is not the correct thing to test for. 
```
available_opts = ['(s)how by ids', '(r)ecover by ids', 'delete (e)ntries', 'recover (a)ll', '(d)elete file', '(q)uit']
```
The correct array should be: `['s', 'r', 'e', 'a', 'd', 'q']`. Also, it needs to be `answer[0]` since answer is an array.

Also, I saw that some `TODOs` in `intelmq/bots/collectors/mail/lib.py` where done, however I have not found a place where that file is actually used. I think it can be deleted.

title: Expand the extra field in output bots

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Currently the extra field is a JSON object encoded as as string. This leads to some (for me) unexpected behaviour when you output the event in JSON format (like in the file output) because you then have a JSON object with one field that is actually another JSON object, but instead of displaying it as such it is encoded as a string. I understand that in some cases you want it as a string, but especially if you are using hierarchical output it does not make much sense to keep it as a string.

I would suggest to add another option (`expand_extra`) to the `to_dict` and `to_json` methods of the `Message` which would expand the field (using `json.loads`) instead of leaving at as string. 

We would then also have to add another parameter to relevant output bots. Making it false by default would ensure that we do not break any existing installations.

This is also somewhat related to #671 . If the field is properly unserialized into a Python dictionary when retrieving it, then it also makes it easier to modify the extra field.

title: `update-asn-data` does not work

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The command `update-asn-data` does not work:

```
# update-asn-data /tmp/asn.db
/usr/local/bin/update-asn-data: line 41: pyasn_util_convert.py: command not found
```

It is because `pyasn_util_convert.py` command is by default installed in `/usr/local/bin/` directory (at least in Ubuntu 14.04), but in `update-asn-data` is specified this:

```
PATH=/bin:/usr/bin
```

I think this PATH definition can be removed or add to end also `/usr/local/bin/` directory

title: postgresql-output fails to recover from temporary connection failure

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

On a production system the Postgresql Output had stoped to write to
the Database, the log showed the following error:

```
  2016-11-18 07:41:04,311 - postgresql-output - ERROR - Executed rollback command after failed query execution.
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/intelmq/bots/outputs/postgresql/output.py", line 64, in process
      self.cur.execute(query, values)
  psycopg2.OperationalError: SSL connection has been closed unexpectedly
```

The error was loged every few milliseconds which made the log grow
about 90GiB over the weekend...

However, the main problem is, that connecting to the DB _was_
possible (so this really should have been only a temporary failure).
But even after restarting the postgres db the bot still continued
throwing above error...  After restarting the bot everything worked
ell again.

title: n6stomp parser classification

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
While trying to create a parser for the n6 HTTP report, I was looking at the n6stomp parser. I thought that I would be able to re-use much of the parser since the format looks to be the same (although I don't know if/where there is any documentation available).

However, the classification seems to introduce a couple of new `classification.type` that are not defined in the [Data-Harmonization](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/master/docs/Data-Harmonization.md):
- account numbers
- leak
- proxy
- tor
- ignore
- other

My understanding was that the Data-Harmonization was an exhaustive list of all possible values for `classification.type`. Is that not correct? 

According to Harmonization-fields.md:

> Furthermore, the value data set should be kept as minimal as possible to avoid “type explosion”, which in turn dilutes the business value of the dynamic typing. 

So, if the Data-Harmonization is not a complete list, can we have a complete list somewhere?

title: JSON structure of events: malware.hash

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
In the IntelMQ the **event** object (`etc/harmonization.conf`) mostly looks like a JSON object. For example `classification.identifier`, `classification.taxonomy`, `destination.abuse_contact`, `destination.geolocation.cc` etc., can be represented as:

```
event
    |
    +- classification
    |   |
    |   +- identifier
    |   +- taxonomy
    |
    +- destination
        |
        +- abuse_contact
        +- geolocation
            |
            +- cc
```

.. and so on. 

But there is one field, called `malware.hash`, which is a string technically and an object logically at the same time:

```
malware.hash      - string (should be an object only)
malware.hash.md5  - string
malware.hash.sha1 - string
```

If someone will want to convert the whole **event** to the multilevel JSON object - he will fail because of this one field.

Could you replace `malware.hash` with `malware.hash.other` (if hash type is unknown) for example? Other name is acceptable.

On the one hand probably many Parsers will have to be updated, but on the other hand you will get a beautiful and correct JSON object.

title: [?] deduplicator expert bot ignores most of the hash bits

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The deduplicator expert bot uses Python's builtin hash mechanism. This has the downside that the number of bits in the hash value is platform dependent: 64 bits on a 64 bit system, 32 bits on a 32 bit system. On 32 bit systems this makes collisions very likely! On 64 bit systems collisions are probably sufficiently unlikely.

Internally, the Event class uses sha256 to compute the hash value but most of that is thrown away. E.g. on a 64 bit system:

```
>>> import intelmq.lib.message
>>> evt = intelmq.lib.message.Event()
>>> hex(hash(evt))
'0x28d5f96f155d335'
>>> hex(evt.__hash__())
'0xe3b0c44298fc1c149afbf4c8996fb92427ae41e4649b934ca495991b7852b855'
```

title: Busy wait with many logentries filling up logfiles with redis

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
We have seen an unusable system because of logfiles filling up the disc.
The cause are several "Empty message received." entries, several per milisecond.

Our hypothesis: 
Introduced with certtools/intelmq/issues/439 (reloading of bots on SIGHUB) by @sebix in
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/commit/e1795d225cfe83a8c381f09f0b49328fbc214385
an exception is caught and receive() which should be blocking returns "None" which
triggers a direct retry in intelmq/lib/bot.py receive_message().

Possible hotfix: Check for 
  `if message is None`
and retry only once.
The question is: Why is the exeception raised and caught in the first place? Our wild idea:
maybe the signal handling procedure does something dirty, so that the first call to redis
fails with the connection erroe. 

```
2016-08-04 14:42:30,551 - shadowserver-parser-Microsoft-Sinkhole - WARNING - Empty message received.
2016-08-04 14:42:30,551 - shadowserver-parser-Microsoft-Sinkhole - WARNING - Empty message received.

title: Allowed protocols for protocol.transport

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Indicates a need for improvements or additions to documentation

body:
protocol.transport must be a list of well known identifiers:

``` bash
cat /etc/protocols
```

I propose that we make this a well known list of enums.
Why?
The current size limit was not an effective test if a given transport protocol is actually valid.
If you look at `/etc/protocols` you'll find that there are longer names than just 6 chars or so.
**But** the list is a list of well known, [IANA registered protocols](https://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/protocol-numbers.xhtml).
So, please let's use that.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

This needs to be cleaned up.

Please replace every public IP with IPs in the form: 1.2.3.4 or 5.6.7.8 or similar - IPs which are obviously test data. 
Please do _not_ replace by RFC1918 IP addresses, because if we want to use that data for full integration tests, an RFC1918 filter might filter these out... So RFC1918 IPs are special IPs for testing.

title: Debian-Packages: permissions of /opt/intelmq problems with .ssh/authorized_keys

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Indicates that a maintainer wants help on an issue or pull request

body:
https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/3e82335a8ee75b525d9c89b87a42c532bd509ed2/debian/intelmq.postinst has the problem that Ubuntu 14.04 sshd does not want to allow connections
via .ssh/authorized_keys if a home directory is group writable.

``` sh
        useradd -d /opt/intelmq -U -s /bin/bash intelmq
    chmod -R g+w /opt/intelmq
```

The resulting error message in /var/log/auth.log looks like

```
Jul  7 17:06:24 ubuntu sshd[10993]: Authentication refused: bad ownership or modes for directory /opt/intelmq
```

intelmq-manager will have to write some files in the directory with the "intelmq" group.
Two possible solutions:
1. check that the top level directory does not need to be written and remove the line
2. use a different home directory for the intelmq user

@swilde created the file initially.

title: Security: Imbox (and other libs) do not validate certificates

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The colleagues from Abusehelper realised some flaws concerning their SSL implementation:
https://github.com/abusesa/abusehelper/blob/master/docs/SECURITY-2016-01.md

@bernhard-herzog reviewed some parts of IntelMQ.

The library "imbox", which is used by the Mail-Collectors, does not validate the certificate of the IMAP Server. It is not possible to force the library to do so.

We also checked: 
- requests: The library does behave well on Ubuntu 14.04
- sleekxmpp: It is possible to tell sleekxmpp to uses a certificate store, currently this is _not_ done

To discuss:
- Remove the dependency of Imbox and do "IMAP by hand"  or persuade Imbox maintainer to add the option to configure SSL.
- Initiate XMPPClient correctly with a CertificateStore
- Create an IntelMQ-Wide usable configuration-variable for a CertificateStore.

title: Multiple issues with Shadowserver Drone Parser

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The Shadowserver Drone Parser does not work as expected.
intelmq/bots/parsers/shadowserver/drone_parser.py
- [x] [l47](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/master/intelmq/bots/parsers/shadowserver/drone_parser.py#L47) `dictreader=True` is not an allowed parameter anymore. I guess this affects all Shadowserver parsers. This is easy to fix
- [x] [l72](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/master/intelmq/bots/parsers/shadowserver/drone_parser.py#L72) If `count = ''` this does not work. This is easy to fix
- [x]  The data I received has different headers than the specification on [Shadowserver.org ](https://www.shadowserver.org/wiki/pmwiki.php/Services/Botnet-Drone-Hadoop)
  Received Data:
  `"timestamp","ip","port","asn","geo","region","city","hostname","type","infection","url","agent","cc_ip","cc_port","cc_asn","cc_geo","cc_dns","count","proxy","application","p0f_genre","p0f_detail","machine_name","id","naics","sic","cc_naics","cc_sic","sector","cc_sector","ssl_cipher","family","tag","public_source"`
- [x] [l66](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/master/intelmq/bots/parsers/shadowserver/drone_parser.py#L66) The field 'cc' is called 'cc_ip' in my Dataset. Documentation differs from reality.
- [x] [l62](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/master/intelmq/bots/parsers/shadowserver/drone_parser.py#L62) assumes that the value in `row['url']` is a valid URL according to the DHO. Unfortunately it is not. It might be required to guess / determine the url. This might be done by deriving it from the fields: `cc_dns`, `application` and `port`. But there might still be some magic involved as those do not always contain a sufficient amount of data to determine the full url.

**EDIT / Solution** 
See https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/issues/524#issuecomment-226443897

title: missing info in the harmonization file: hash.md5, hash.sha1, etc.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
There is a problem with assuming the implicit declaration of hash functions by prefixing them with $1$ etc . in the events table / data harmonization config file:
- assume you are given a hash (sha1) of a piece of malware and you want to find it in the events table.
  However, you only stored the md5 since that is what you received even though the sender sent you both fields (sha1 and md4 - such as the n6 feed). Then you can not ever find the right entry again.

Solution: we unfortunately need to extend the harmonization.conf file:
Include 
- `malware.hash.sha1`
- `malware.hash.md5`
- `malware.hash.sha256`

Sorry...

title: Exception in file utils.py - function reverse_readline - python 3

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
When using python 3.4, when someone try to see the logs in intelmq-manager the following exception occurs in the function reverse_readline in file utils.py:

```
 File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/intelmq-1.0.0-py3.4.egg/intelmq/lib/utils.py", line 243, in reverse_readline
    handle.seek(-offset, os.SEEK_END)
io.UnsupportedOperation: can't do nonzero end-relative seeks
```

Since python 3.2 that these arguments are not possible to use in the function seek, I've changed the code of the function and this fix works, here's the code:

``` python
def reverse_readline(filename, buf_size=8192):
    with open(filename) as qfile:
        qfile.seek(0, os.SEEK_END)
        position = totalsize = qfile.tell()
        line = ''
        if buf_size < position:
            qfile.seek(totalsize-buf_size-1)
            char = qfile.read(1)
            while char != '\n':
                char = qfile.read(1)
            buffersize = totalsize-qfile.tell()
            number = totalsize-buf_size
        while position >= number:
            qfile.seek(position)
            next_char = qfile.read(1)
            if next_char == "\n":
                yield line[:: 1]
                line = ''
            else:
                line += next_char
            position -= 1
        yield line[:: 1]
```

Regards

title: Missing gnutls/gnutls.h on Debian 8 due to missing libgnutls28-dev

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Indicates a need for improvements or additions to documentation

body:
I was installing intelmq on a headless Debian 8 machine following the Python3 instructions when I encountered an error in my install. After typing in `pip3 install -r REQUIREMENTS`  in the [installation instructions](https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/blob/master/docs/User-Guide.md#python-34-recommended-1) I encountered an fatal error that stated that I was missing `gnutls/gnutls.h:` 

It seems that on headless Debian installations libgnutls28-dev is not installed and is required for these instructions to finish. I ran `apt-get install libgnutls28-dev` and re-tried `pip3 install -r REQUIREMENTS` and it completed successfully. It might make sense to add libgnutls28-dev to the apt-get instructions just in case a user is on a headless system that does not have it installed by the user-space packages.

title: "time.source" field is not filled up with some bots

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
We have a problem with some bots which don't provide a `time.source` field. At the recipient (ISP, network operator ) side, there is no way someone can find such an IP address in large log files without a timestamp (and time zone)!

Hence we have a few options:
1. we provide time info via `time.observation` (i.e. when we found the event in some blocklist etc) **and** provide a way to verify our claim (for example: "is an open recursive DNS server") - something that people can check themselves, or...
2. we ignore these events intentionally since they create more work for the recipient without adding any value.

So, I think we need to go through each bot/parser and see which case applies and act accordingly.

title: dga collector downloads its data too often under certain conditions

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: help wanted
labels.description: Indicates that a maintainer wants help on an issue or pull request

body:
I noticed with the DGA collector bot that a weird error condition can occur:
1. the collector bot will download the data (it is a lot of data!)
2. the disk is full -> redis will have a pipeline error
3. the bot will through a stack trace and retry in error_retry_delay (= 15 sec by default) again.
4. goto 1. 

-> therefore the collector bot will create a huge load on the source feed's site and download a large file every 15 seconds. That's too much.

title: FQDN with trailing dot or not?

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
The current implementation allows bots variants, with and without the trailing dot for the root zone. Sanitize does not add or remove it.

```
>>> intelmq.lib.harmonization.FQDN.is_valid(u'foobar.example.')
True
>>> intelmq.lib.harmonization.FQDN.is_valid(u'foobar.example')
True
>>> intelmq.lib.harmonization.FQDN.sanitize(u'foobar.example')
u'foobar.example'
>>> intelmq.lib.harmonization.FQDN.sanitize(u'foobar.example.')
u'foobar.example.'
```

This can potentially lead to duplicates.

Which variant do you prefer?

title: BUG: http(s)?_proxy ENV variables still seem to be needed (even if specified in defaults.conf)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
So, I noticed that when you restart a bot or the botnet via intelmqctl , you need to have the $http_proxy and $https_proxy env variables set, otherwise it will not use the proxy. 
This even happens when the settings are entered into etc/defaults.conf .

IMHO the proxy settings from etc/defaults.conf should be used in any case.

title: Custom python environment

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
When you install IntelMQ assuming you'll use python 3, there is no way to tell intelmq it should run with the python 3 environment (except for changing the default of the whole system).

I think one of the more flexible approaches would be to have a environment variable like INTELMQ_PYTHON which would define the executable used to run intelmq, so... if there was no environment variable the default "python" would be used, but we could do something like:

```
export INTELMQ_PYTHON=python3
```

and from this point forward everything in intelmq would use the python3 executable.

What do you think?

title: Bot terminated on redis connection issues

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
I have an issue with deduplicator bot (actually in my it happens mostly on deduplicator, however as it is on the bot level, it could happen to any bot). As the bot intercepts an issue with redis connection (the first timeout) it tries to reconnect once and dies. 

Redis server restarts meanwhile, however the bot is stopped already and breaks the pipeline. According to the configuration below, I would expect the bot to wait 120s and try again, however that does not happen. Am I right, that this situation should also be included in the "retry process"?

``` json
    "deduplicator-expert": {
        "error_dump_message": true,
        "error_log_message": true,
        "error_max_retries": 100,
        "error_procedure": "pass",
        "error_retry_delay": 120,
        "ignore_keys": "raw,time.observation",
        "redis_cache_db": "6",
        "redis_cache_host": "127.0.0.1",
        "redis_cache_port": "6379",
        "redis_cache_ttl": "86400"
    }
```

title: travis fixes and test

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: feature request
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Indicates a need for improvements or additions to documentation

body:
- `Event()` constructor takes optional argument: instance of report, fields `raw`, `feed.(name|url)`, `time.observation` are copied if existing. reduces duplicate code.
- Changes for travis and Python 3 requirements
- Tests requiring local dbs are skipped unless these files exits
- using `setup_travis.py` sudo and `/opt/intelmq` are no longer needed.
- documentation on bots started (with experts)
- removed EBNF crap from Data-Harmonization docs.
- New field `classification.identifier` plus docs
- BOTS: switched most sources to HTTPS, updated description for some
- asn-lookup ignores IPv6 until fixed upstream -> no errors and stopping bots.
- ripencc bot has two more sources to get abuse contacts for AS and IP
- Fix in cache for non-string values
- fixed timezone handling for `harmonization.DateTime.from_timestamp`

body:
Addresses some of the bug reports recently brought up.

And all tested components are Python 3 compatible, except for the parsers using unicodeccsv. Try running `nosetests3` :)
The changes needed to make it compatible brought some encoding issues up, and it actually solves some issues with the built-in csv parser. So I guess it will run better on 3 than on 2 ...

title: IPv6 handling

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Currently, many bots do not support IPv6 addresses and are either failing or silently ignoring IPv6 values.

What is the projects policy for IPv6?

If it's not supported yet, there are two possible approaches:
- IPv6 can be ignored if not supported by bots.
- Bots may fail with IPv6 data.

title: Should we force to have both proxies?

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
In the lib of the http collector we have:

``` python
...
    if http_proxy and https_proxy:
        proxy = urllib2.ProxyHandler({'http': http_proxy, 'https': https_proxy })
...
```

Should we force to have both proxies or does it make sense to test one of them, like this:

``` python
...
    if http_proxy or https_proxy:
        proxy = urllib2.ProxyHandler({'http': http_proxy, 'https': https_proxy })
...
```

invalid key 'classification.taxonomy'

title: cymru_whois is broken in beta version

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
Hello (again).. 

```
2015-06-08 22:37:21,222 - cymru-whois-expert - ERROR - global name 'socket' is not defined
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/intelmq-1.0.0-py2.7.egg/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 101, in start
    self.process()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/intelmq-1.0.0-py2.7.egg/intelmq/bots/experts/cymru_whois/expert.py", line 36, in process
    ip_integer = IPAddress.to_int(ip)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/intelmq-1.0.0-py2.7.egg/intelmq/lib/harmonization.py", line 155, in to_int
    except socket.error:
NameError: global name 'socket' is not defined
```

And indeed it miss a "export socket" in lib/harmonization.py

Then....

```
global name 'ip' is not defined 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/intelmq-1.0.0-py2.7.egg/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 101, in start
    self.process()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/intelmq-1.0.0-py2.7.egg/intelmq/bots/experts/cymru_whois/expert.py", line 36, in process
    ip_integer = IPAddress.to_int(ip)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/intelmq-1.0.0-py2.7.egg/intelmq/lib/harmonization.py", line 154, in to_int
    ip_integer = socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET, ip)
NameError: global name 'ip' is not defined
```

need to change Ip by value here..

```
    @staticmethod
    def to_int(value):
        try:
            ip_integer = socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET, value)
        except socket.error:
            try:
                ip_integer = socket.inet_pton(socket.AF_INET6, value)
            except socket.error:
                return None
```

Finally...

```
Check the following exception: 
local variable 'minimum' referenced before assignment
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/intelmq-1.0.0-py2.7.egg/intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 101, in start
    self.process()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/intelmq-1.0.0-py2.7.egg/intelmq/bots/experts/cymru_whois/expert.py", line 43, in process
    cache_key = bin(ip_integer)[2 : minimum + 2]
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'minimum' referenced before assignment
```

The test wait an int and the result of version is a string.. quick fix with casting...

```
  ip_version = int(IPAddress.version(ip))
            ip_integer = IPAddress.to_int(ip)

            if ip_version == 4:
                minimum = MINIMUM_BGP_PREFIX_IPV4
            elif ip_version == 6:
                minimum = MINIMUM_BGP_PREFIX_IPV6
```

Pull request : https://github.com/certtools/intelmq/pull/220

That's quickly what I see. but maybe it need better fix for ip_version. Because they're is a lot of misses.. for example hphost feed give "source.fqdn" and it trigger nothing.

Is it scheduled to have a dedicated bot "host 2 ip" before ? a host could have many ip's. Or this plug should do all the stuff ?

title: PostgreSQL Encoding Error

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
```
2014-08-01 19:45:52,379 - postgresql - ERROR - Current Message(event): 'feed=dragonresearchgroup, city=Gda\xc5\x84sk, reported_ip=83.3.130.101, feed_ur
l=http://dragonresearchgroup.org/insight/vncprobe.txt, source_time=2014-07-28T02:48:02, cc=PL, ip=83.3.130.101, observation_time=2014-08-01T15:25:10.49
9358, source_ip=83.3.130.101, reported_asn=5617, as_name="TPNET Orange Polska Spolka Akcyjna,PL", bgp_prefix=83.0.0.0/13, longitude=18.6583, reported_a
s_name="TPNET Orange Polska Spolka Akc", taxonomy="Intrusion Attempts", latitude=54.3608, allocated=2003-12-03, cymru_cc=PL, type=brute-force, asn=5617
, registry=ripencc'

2014-08-01 19:45:52,379 - postgresql - ERROR - Check the following exception:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "intelmq/lib/bot.py", line 51, in start
    self.process()
  File "/root/intelmq/intelmq/bots/outputs/postgresql/postgresql.py", line 35, in process
    self.cur.execute(query, values)
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\u0144' in position 3: ordinal not in range(128)

2014-08-01 19:45:52,379 - postgresql - ERROR - Pipeline connection failed (UnicodeEncodeError('ascii', u'Gda\u0144sk', 3, 4, 'ordinal not in range(128)
'))

2014-08-01 19:45:52,379 - postgresql - INFO - Pipeline will reconnect in 30 seconds
```

```
postgres@intelmq:~$ psql -l
                             List of databases
   Name    |  Owner   | Encoding  | Collate | Ctype |   Access privileges   
-----------+----------+-----------+---------+-------+-----------------------
 intelmq   | intelmq  | SQL_ASCII | C       | C     | 
 postgres  | postgres | SQL_ASCII | C       | C     | 
```

**FIX**

```
postgres@intelmq:~$ psql 
psql (9.1.13)
Type "help" for help.

postgres=# update pg_database set encoding = pg_char_to_encoding('UTF8') where datname = 'intelmq';
```

```
postgres@intelmq:~$ psql -l
                             List of databases
   Name    |  Owner   | Encoding  | Collate | Ctype |   Access privileges   
-----------+----------+-----------+---------+-------+-----------------------
 intelmq   | intelmq  | UTF8      | C       | C     | 
 postgres  | postgres | SQL_ASCII | C       | C     | 
```

**'observation time'** field:
- should be a mandatory field
- should be defined as soon as possible (parser bot may do this)

We need to think how can we do without add a new extra detail in all system that will create more complexity for user.

Accepting suggestions :)
